results.creator_credit: Deb Cox, Fiona Eagger, Every Cloud Productions and Screen Australia

results.title: Stories of Labassa
results.brief_description: The historic mansion ‘Labassa’ in Melbourne has seen many occupants and much activity in its more than 150 years of existence. Bronwyn Worrall, who manages the property for the community heritage organisation, the National Trust of Australia (Victoria), discusses the building’s history as a family residence, a home for ‘hippies’ in the 1970s and its use as a location for a number of films.

results.title: The Telegram Man
results.creator_credit: James Khehtie, Ceinwen Berry and Victoria Wharfe McIntyre
results.brief_description: Multi-award-winning film ‘The Telegram Man’ poignantly depicts the human cost of war in its portrayal of relationships impacted by the vicissitudes of wartime. Featuring restrained but deeply emotional performances from some of Australia’s finest screen actors (Jack Thompson, Gary Sweet and Sigrid Thornton), this is a powerful film about loss, grief and duty.
results.creator_credit_for_label: James Khehtie, Ceinwen Berry and Victoria Wharfe McIntyre

results.title: [Cinesound Review 1950-1965]
results.brief_description:
This film contains excerpts from Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The film features a number of different clips from newsreels between 1950 and 1965.

The first section, titled ‘1950 Melbourne Cup’, shows the horse race at Flemington Racecourse, photographed by Ron Horner. The film includes close-ups of people in the crowd, and commentary of the race as Comic Court wins. This is followed by a section titled ‘Scone Rodeo: Bronchos (sic) on the Bust’, featuring footage of a horse rodeo in Scone, New South Wales.

The third section, titled ‘Fur Flies: Battling Budgerigar K.O.’s Cat’ features a playfight between two pets, a ginger cat and a budgerigar. In the fourth section we see ANZAC Day parades in Melbourne and Sydney, preluded by the title ‘ANZAC: Nation’s Homage’.

The fifth section is titled ‘Skiing: Day and Night Fun at Mt. Buller’, with commentary by David Low. It features children learning how to ski and social activities in the resorts, including bands and dancing. This is followed by an excerpt called ‘Clark Well Ahead’, showing the motorcar race at the 1965 British Grand Prix, won by Jim Clark.

The film ends with a cartoon called ‘Local Boy Makes Good: A Story with a Moral’ and three feature film trailers: ‘The Counterfeit Traitor’ (1962), ‘Pollyanna’ (1960) and ‘Mein Kampf’ (1960).

results.title: My City Walkabout
results.creator_credit: Emmie Seaton, Mateuse Pingol and MatEm Productions
results.brief_description: ‘My City Walkabout’ is a film with a French New Wave aesthetic that follows an Aboriginal man searching for his place in modern Australian society. Set in the man’s dream, the film explores magic realism sequences to illustrate the protagonist’s desire to alter his reality and ultimately find his identity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Emmie Seaton, Mateuse Pingol and MatEm Productions

results.title: A Notable tree
results.brief_description: This is the story of a boab tree in Darwin, enduring the test of time, witnessing the changes that take place around it. As it ages, it becomes a monument of nature and a symbol of survival through the history of Darwin. The Adonsonia Gregorii is a bottle-shaped tree endemic to Australia. Some trees can live over one thousand years. Some refer to them as “The Tree of Life”.

results.title: Survival of the fittest
results.creator_credit: St Mary's Anglican Girls' College and Tessa Laing
results.brief_description: ‘Survival of the Fittest’ constructs the core message that human genetics should not be altered, despite good intentions. Based on a scientific theory by Herbert Spencer that relates to how organisms evolve over time to develop desirable traits. The film explores how scientists can artificially replicate a natural process, which can lead to a negative outcome.

results.title: Zembla
results.creator_credit: Katrina Salvadore and St Columba's College
results.brief_description: Zembla is a word derived from “zemblanity”, a term coined by the British author William Boyd to mean “the opposite of serendipity”.
